Federated Learning is Better with
Non-Homomorphic Encryption

Konstantin Burlachenko AI Initiative, KAUSTThuwalSaudi Arabia ,  Abdulmajeed Alrowithi Saudi Data and AI AuthorityRiyadhSaudi Arabia ,  Fahad Ali Albalawi Saudi Data and AI AuthorityRiyadhSaudi Arabia  and  Peter Richtárik AI Initiative, KAUSTThuwalSaudi Arabia
(2023)
Abstract.

Traditional AI methodologies necessitate centralized data collection, which becomes impractical when facing problems with network communication, data privacy, or storage capacity. Federated Learning (FL) offers a paradigm that empowers distributed AI model training without collecting raw data. There are different choices for providing privacy during FL training. One of the popular methodologies is employing Homomorphic Encryption (HE) - a breakthrough in privacy-preserving computation from Cryptography. However, these methods have a price in the form of extra computation and memory footprint. To resolve these issues, we propose an innovative framework that synergizes permutation-based compressors with Classical Cryptography, even though employing Classical Cryptography was assumed to be impossible in the past in the context of FL. Our framework offers a way to replace HE with cheaper Classical Cryptography primitives which provides security for the training process. It fosters asynchronous communication and provides flexible deployment options in various communication topologies.

Federated Learning, Privacy Preserving Machine Learning, Asynchronous Training, Security, Optimization, AES, CKKS.

1. Introduction

Effective machine learning models necessitate vast training data from diverse sources (Zhang et al., 2020). However, such data, often dispersed across various entities, faces sharing restrictions due to privacy concerns (Jiang et al., 2021; Liu et al., 2022). Federated learning (FL) provides a viable solution, enabling collaborative global model training without exposing sensitive information (McMahan et al., 2017; Kairouz et al., 2021). FL algorithms bifurcate into cross-device FL, involving big amount of devices, and cross-silo FL, typically engaging several distinct organizations (Liu et al., 2022). In both cases, preserving the privacy of clients’ datasets is significant. FL strives to ensure confidentiality by retaining private data on the client side, yet it falls short of providing substantial privacy assurance. Model parameters and derived quantities from it, transmitted from clients to a server, may embed sensitive data (see Appendix E.1). Detailed information about privacy methods for FL is presented in Appendix D. We briefly discuss two of them.

Differential Privacy (DP) is an approach to assess the privacy of a specific Algorithm provided by Dwork et al. (2006a, b). DP algorithms ensure that, for any set of training examples, no attacker, no matter how powerful, can not learn much more information about a single training example than they could if this example had been excluded from the training data. Despite offering privacy protection for individual users, integrating DP with FL could amplify communication overhead, diminish accuracy. When striving for strong privacy guarantees in scenarios where the user count is small (which is possible in cross-silo settings) the noise impact from DP technics makes training challenging. Understanding the convergence of SGD with DP is an active research topic (Chen et al., 2020).

While DP statistically hides the training data, Homomorphic Encryption (HE) provides means to perform computation operations under encrypted numbers from ℤdsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathbb{Z}^{d}, ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, 𝔹dsuperscript𝔹𝑑\mathbb{B}^{d} without decryption, protecting input and output from execution part. Therefore HE can be used for aggregating encrypted gradients (Liu et al., 2019; Aono et al., 2017) in a server that clients do not trust, given that master has a public key.

Classical Cryptography in FL

Classical Cryptography operates on the binary representation of data. It does not preserve even linear relations in a homomorphic way. The fact of exhibiting poor algebraic properties is an underlying reason why using Classical Cryptography was considered challenging by previous research papers (Kaissis et al., 2020; Jain and Cherukuri, 2023). In these works, authors stated that Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) (Daemen and Rijmen, 2001) is not suitable for FL or is challenging.

Communication Compression in FL

Numerous compression methods such as quantization (Wen et al., 2017; Safaryan and Richtárik, 2019), sparsification (Wangni et al., 2018; Alistarh et al., 2018), and dithering (Alistarh et al., 2017; Horvóth et al., 2022) have been explored to mitigate communication cost during FL training. However, these techniques necessitate secure server-side aggregation, and there are no guarantees that communication reduction techniques and techniques aimed to preserve privacy or security are combinable.

Research Contributions

We discovered that recently proposed permutated correlated compressors (Szlendak et al., 2021) PermK exhibit properties essential for using Classical Cryptography in FL while preserving the ability of Communication Compression. In our work, we introduce a framework that provides privacy and secure preserving training process to FL applications in which previously HE methods have been used. Summary of our contributions:

  1. (1)

    We addressed the challenge previously mentioned in (Kaissis et al., 2020; Jain and Cherukuri, 2023) that usage of AES is challenging in FL.

  2. (2)

    We demonstrated the operational advantages of the proposed privacy and secure aware optimization Alg. 3 over HE in the setting in which HE is typically applied in FL.

  3. (3)

    We illustrated the framework’s capability to train ResNet-18 (He et al., 2016a) DL model in CIFAR-10, and carried the discussion of potential benefits for DL in Appendix I.

  4. (4)

    We demonstrated a possibility of computation communication overlap and handling compute heterogeneity in Appendix H.2. Deployment flexibility in communication topologies is discussed in Appendix J.

To support readers with various backgrounds we provide (i) glossary in Appendix A; (ii) details about AES in Appendix F; (iii) overview of privacy mechanisms in FL in Appendix D, discussion about the difference between privacy and security in Appendix E.2; (iv) overview of CKKS in Appendix G (see Table of Content at p.Appendix).

2. Problem Formulation

In this work, we develop a practical communication efficient privacy and secure aware framework for FL training.

Requirements for Optimization Objective

From the perspective of machine learning (ML), our objective is to select a function from a parameterized function class ℱℱ\mathcal{F} indexed by x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, by solving the following optimization problem:

The function fi:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} provides the score criteria for using the model F^​(⋅;x)^𝐹⋅𝑥\hat{F}(\cdot;x) on the client’s i𝑖i data. In the context of FL the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} typically represented as:

The weight wi∈ℝsubscript𝑤𝑖ℝw_{i}\in\mathbb{R} encodes knowledge about the role of client i𝑖i. We aim to solve Problem 1 under the next requirements:

Security Requirements for the FL Training Procedure.
  1. (A)

    Clients never transfer the training data to the master.

  2. (B)

    Clients do not trust communication devices.

  3. (C)

    Detect attempts of message tampering by adversaries.

  4. (D)

    Clients distrust a server to store information that could compromise the training data.

  5. (E)

    Preventing competitor worker interference.

  6. (F)

    Limit memory traffic from clients to the master.

  7. (G)

    Overlapping communication and computing in clients because separate physical devices implement it.

Assumptions for applying our framework

(i) f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) is differentiable in training variable x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}; (ii) Clients trust each other through the established key; (iii) dom​(f)=ℝddom𝑓superscriptℝ𝑑\mathrm{dom}(f)=\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Real-world scenarios for applying our framework

(a) An individual using multiple IoT devices and wants to train an ML model via servers provided by a third-party company. In reality, engineers in the companies may have unlimited access to server software facilities and this social aspect should be considered while making a decision about sending plain messages to servers; (b) In cross-device settings several IoT mutually trusted clients perform FL training, but still there is a need to have a master: some client is temporarily unavailable and updates should be buffered; applied steps need to be stored to reconstruct the optimization trajectory for further statistical tests, but IoT devices do not have the needed storage capacity; the training should be restarted in critical system failures; (c) We want to train FL model without a physical master in a situation when communication topology effectively supports broadcasting. Our framework can be instantiated in this regime (see Appendix J).

3. Framework of Security Aware FL with Permuted Compressors

The Distributed Compressed Gradient Descent (DCGD (Baseline)) (Khirirat et al., 2018), presented as (Algorithm 1, Option B), enables the use of independent unbiased compressors 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} if 𝔼​[‖𝒞i​(x)−x‖2]≤w​‖x‖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑥𝑥2𝑤superscriptnorm𝑥2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq w\|x\|^{2}. If w≠0𝑤0w\neq 0 this algorithm does not induce variance for a μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex objective f𝑓f only in a specific (overparameterized) mode: ∇fi​(x)=0,∀i∈[n]formulae-sequence∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥0for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\nabla f_{i}(x)=0,\forall i\in[n]. If 𝒞i​(∇fi​(x))=def∇fi​(x)superscriptdefsubscript𝒞𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\mathcal{C}_{i}(\nabla f_{i}(x))\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\nabla f_{i}(x), it reconstitutes distributed Gradient Descent (GD). One line of research involves removing variance from the use of compressors. For instance, MARINA (Gorbunov et al., 2021) and COFIG/FRECON (Zhao et al., 2021) do not induce variance when using unbiased independent compressors, while EF21 (Richtárik et al., 2021) avoids inducing variance from any independent contractive compressors. In all these algorithms, the logic in the master starts to include extra state updates based on obtaining messages from clients. But this is what we aim to avoid. Thus, the development of our framework is based on stateless DCGD (Baseline). For plain DCGD (Baseline) we have two issues: (a) In Line 6, the algorithm sends sparsified information about ∇fi​(x)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\nabla f_{i}(x) to the master, which is insecure; (b) In Line 8, the master computes the average of gik∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑g_{i}^{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, but the master should not obtain gik=∇fi​(xk)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑘g_{i}^{k}=\nabla f_{i}(x^{k}) or quantities that are subject to reconstruction attacks (see Appendix E.1). One way to address these problems is to use the HE schemes. The current practical state-of-the-art HE scheme which works ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} is the CKKS (Cheon et al., 2017). The CKKS scheme is the most prevalent for ML applications (Lauter et al., 2022) and is a practical one. As we will demonstrate in experiments, the CKKS carries an approximation error that arises due to the scheme being lossy by design. See Appendix G, D for details about CKKS and HE.

The clients need to send in parallel n𝑛n encrypted messages to the master. Since clients trust each other, symmetric key encryption is a natural option to use. In the world of symmetric ciphers, we have decided to use a block cipher, specifically the industry-standard AES (Daemen and Rijmen, 1999), instead of stream ciphers like SALSA (Bernstein, 2008). The choice was made due to the advantages of block ciphers, as: (i) hardware support within CPU 111AES support: Intel x86 Westmere, AMD x86 Bulldozer, ARM Cortex-A53; (ii) the provision of multiple security levels (128,192,256128192256128,192,256 bits); (iii) the necessary flexibility to work with available parts of the vector Gksuperscript𝐺𝑘G^{k} (In coming Algorithm 3). The AES block-cipher provides security for a single 16-byte block. The Modes of Operation provide a way to use AES for more than one block. Message Authentication Code (MAC) provides guarantees from tampering. In our work, we used AES/EAX mode of operation. For details about AES see Appendix F.

The naive way to use AES is to use Algorithm 1, (Option A). It solves problems with an untrusted server and channels. Without knowing s​k𝑠𝑘sk, the untrusted party cannot join the training procedure. Due to the use of MAC (Lines 5, 13), the training process verifies the integrity and protects against malicious attacks. To provide semantic security against a chosen-plaintext attack (CPA) and have the ability to use s​k𝑠𝑘sk in a distributed way, we employ random n​o​n​c​e𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒nonce based selection. It eliminates the need for client coordination in a n​o​n​c​e𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒nonce selection if n​o​n​c​e𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒nonce is big enough such as 128128128 bits. Details about the role of n​o​n​c​e𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒nonce in block ciphers are presented in Appendix F.

With this Algorithm 1 Option-A, solves (A)–(E). However, this strategy has two big downsides: (1) Computation at Lines 13 and 14 is repeated by all clients with complexity per client 𝒪​(d​n)𝒪𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}(dn); (2) Amount of information from the master in Line 9 is 𝒪​(d​n)𝒪𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}(dn), not 𝒪​(d)𝒪𝑑\mathcal{O}(d). We pay this price due to the use of AES, which does not allow to perform aggregation in the server. From one point of view, the natural way is to perform averaging for vectors in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} in the master (Line 10), but on another side, we perform bit-wise operations (Line 5) inside AES cipher. There is no way to connect it from the first point of view, but we have discovered how to do it!

The PermK correlated compressor from work (Szlendak et al., 2021) possesses a compelling property that has yet to be recognized. The correlated compressors operate interdependently for clients and the schema was outlined in Algorithm 2. Let 𝒞1,…,𝒞n:ℝd→ℝd:subscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝑛→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{C}_{n}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} be randomized PermK compressors, then

𝔼​[1n​∑i=1n𝒞i​(vi)]=1n​∑i=1nvi,∀vi∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑣𝑖for-allsubscript𝑣𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{C}_{i}(v_{i})\right]=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}v_{i},\forall v_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

If d≥n𝑑𝑛d\geq n, then 1n​∑i=1n𝒞i​(vi)1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{C}_{i}(v_{i}) fulfills the variance bound:

𝔼​[‖1n​∑i=1n𝒞i​(vi)−1n​∑i=1nvi‖2]≤1n​∑i=1n‖vi‖2−‖1n​∑i=1nvi‖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑣𝑖21𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑖2superscriptnorm1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑣𝑖2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathcal{C}_{i}(v_{i})-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}v_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|v_{i}\right\|^{2}-\left\|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}v_{i}\right\|^{2}

.

This compressor is used in our DCGD/PermK Algorithm 3. Its unbiasedness property ensures the absence of systematic errors and the variance bound guarantees that if we are in an overparameterized setting and xk→x∗→superscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑥x^{k}\to x^{*}, then the estimator’s variance will decay to zero, which should remove any oscillation behavior near the solution. The crucial property of DCGD/PermK is that the aggregation of compressed gradients can be replaced by concatenation, which is algebraic monoid for (ℝ∗,concat)superscriptℝconcat(\mathbb{R}^{*},\mathrm{concat}), and not the algebraic group. Scaling an encrypted vector by 1n1𝑛\frac{1}{n} is unfeasible in the master, but this can be delegated to the iterate update Algorithm 3, Line 17. We can use non-secure pseudo-random generators as (Matsumoto and Nishimura, 1998) for sampling indices because they are independent of the input.

4. The Resilience for Attacks

In chosen-plaintext-attack (CPA), an attacker may adaptively ask for the encryption (e1,…)subscript𝑒1…(e_{1},\dots) of arbitrary messages (m1,…)subscript𝑚1…(m_{1},\dots) to obtain the ability to correctly guess from the set of two encrypted cipher-texts {E1,E2}subscript𝐸1subscript𝐸2\{E_{1},E_{2}\} which encryption belongs to which message in the set {M1,M2}subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2\{M_{1},M_{2}\}, given that attacker knows the set {M1,M2}subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2\{M_{1},M_{2}\}. CKKS and AES in EAX mode of operation (Bellare et al., 2004) are secure against CPA.

In a chosen-ciphertext-attack (CCA), the attacker has unlimited access to a decryption oracle, with the same goal as in CPA. All HE schemas cannot achieve CCA security (Fauzi et al., 2022). It has been proved that AES/EAX is secure against CCA (Bellare et al., 2004).

The algorithms executed in general-purpose microprocessors from an execution point of view are a stream of instructions. However, the energy consumption for different operations is different (Horowitz, 2014). It leads to the possibility of side-channel attacks, where the attacker can use information about physical leakages when the number (or type) of operations is some function of secret key or plaintext. The AES block cipher and Operation Modes perform the same stream of operation types (see Appendix F). In CKKS polynomial multiplication, encoding, decoding, and randomization can lead to a trace to plain message (Aydin et al., 2022) using side-channel attacks. During the past time from standardization of AES the works targeted to protect AES from side-channel attacks have been carried (Rahaman and Hossain, 2008), (Gross et al., 2017).

Protecting HE libraries from side-channel attacks is an open question. For example, according to (Aydin et al., 2022) the HE implementation in a reference SEAL library (Chen et al., 2017) and any derived libraries such as TenSEAL (Benaissa et al., 2021) requires protection against side-channel attacks. The work describes how to exploit an asymmetry in ciphertext generation and decrease the security level from 2128superscript21282^{128} to 24.4superscript24.42^{4.4} for Brakerski/Fan-Vercauteren(BFV) (Fan and Vercauteren, 2012) Ring Learning With Error (RLWE) (see Appendix G.1). Therefore, protection from side-channel attacks for AES can be considered to be more well-developed.

5. Experiments

We made an experimental comparison of several optimization algorithms with different compression and security methods. In Table LABEL:tbl:list_of_optimization_algos presented in Appendix B we summarized their qualitative aspects.

5.1. Synthetic Experiments

We’re going to illustrate the advantages of employing block cipher AES (see Appendix F), as opposed to the CKKS (see Appendix G). The experiments were conducted on a simulated environment using FL_PyTorch (Burlachenko et al., 2021). Details on the computing environment are in Appendix E.1. We configured the CKKS to offer security guarantees as AES with 128128128 bit (161616 bytes) key. In this case, the size of public and private keys for CKKS has a lower bound 420 000420000420\,000 bytes (see Appendix G for underlying reason). During usage of CKKS, the public key should be reported somehow to the master once. As we will see while using DCGD/PermK/AES no key at all should be reported to master for master to operate. Therefore the key size can be a problem for CKKS already when the volume of communicated information is far smaller than 0.42⋅106⋅0.42superscript1060.42\cdot 10^{6} Bytes. In our experiments, we ignore the overhead from key negotiations between parties.

Optimization Problem and Experimental Setup

In our synthetically controlled experiments, we consider a specific smooth convex optimization problem which is obtained from Equation 1 via fi​(x)=1ni​‖Ai​x−bi‖2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\|A_{i}x-b_{i}\|^{2}, Ai∈ℝni×d,bi∈ℝdformulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑑subscript𝑏𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑A_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}\times d},b_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Case 1: Distributed GD with/without AES/CKKS

We conducted experiments with d=1000𝑑1000d=1000, n=50𝑛50n=50, and ni=12subscript𝑛𝑖12n_{i}=12. In our designed experimental setup we filled the Hessian ∇2f​(x)superscript∇2𝑓𝑥\nabla^{2}f(x) such that its nonzero eigenvalues lie uniformly in [1.0,10.0]1.010.0[1.0,10.0], therefore Lf=10subscript𝐿𝑓10L_{f}=10. We used the maximum theoretical constant step size γ=1/Lf𝛾1subscript𝐿𝑓\gamma=1/L_{f} for GD. Fig. 1 (a) shows the impact of IEEE-754 FP16, FP32, and FP64 formats. It shows that GD/AES does not hurt float arithmetic. However, GD/AES increases traffic between the master and clients by a factor of n𝑛n as we see from Fig. 1 (b) and increases wall clock time by a factor of 1.7 as in Fig. 1 (c). Next, Fig. 2 compares GD with AES and CKKS. According to Fig. 2 (a), GD/CKKS and FP64 arithmetic, it’s possible to obtain |∇f​(xk)|2≈10−9superscript∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘2superscript109|\nabla f(x^{k})|^{2}\approx 10^{-9}, when GD/AES attains |∇f​(xk)|2≈10−23superscript∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘2superscript1023|\nabla f(x^{k})|^{2}\approx 10^{-23}. From Fig. 2 (b), (c) we see that GD/CKKS increases load from master slightly compared to GD/AES, but increases the load from clients by ×104absentsuperscript104\times 10^{4}. As per Fig. 2 (d), CKKS is approximately ×3absent3\times 3 slower compared to AES. Using GD/AES is reasonable only if d𝑑d and n𝑛n are small.

Case 2: DCGD with AES/CKKS

In this experiment, we employ DCGD with RandK sparsification compressor to analyze the possibility of gradient sparsification while preserving client’s privacy from the master. To compress ∇fi​(x)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\nabla f_{i}(x) each client creates a set Si⊂{1,2,…,d}subscript𝑆𝑖12…𝑑S_{i}\subset\{1,2,\dots,d\} of size K𝐾K chosen uniformly at random, and compute C​(∇fi​(x))=defdK​∑j∈Si[∇fi​(x)]j⋅ejsuperscriptdef𝐶∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑑𝐾subscript𝑗subscript𝑆𝑖⋅subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑗subscript𝑒𝑗C(\nabla f_{i}(x))\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\frac{d}{K}\sum_{j\in S_{i}}[\nabla f_{i}(x)]_{j}\cdot e_{j}, where ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j} are unit vectors of standard basis of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. Results are presented in Fig. 3, and Fig. 4. Fig. 3 (a) and Fig. 4 (a) demonstrates that using AES does not lead to numerical issues, whereas CKKS for FP64 does. In GD, the master broadcasts a vector from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} in each round. For DCGD/RandK/AES, if clients can reconstruct sparsified indices, then the master has to broadcast d=K⋅n=15⋅n𝑑⋅𝐾𝑛⋅15𝑛d=K\cdot n=\frac{1}{5}\cdot n encrypted scalars and 32​n32𝑛32n bytes from employing nonce, and mac for privacy and integrity. This process reduces the number of bits transmitted from the master to the clients by a factor ×5absent5\times 5, compared to standard GD/AES, as depicted in Fig. 3 (b) and Fig. 1 (b). Fig. 4 (c) shows that CKKS does not leverage the sparsity. For HE schemas, encoding of any two vectors (e.g. sparse and dense) should be indistinguishable due to semantic security requirements. However, from a computational perspective, ignoring sparsity is sometimes highly impractical, and this gap presents an open research question for HE. Fig. 4 (b) highlights that AES adapts to any bit representation of scalars. In contrast, TenSEAL (Benaissa et al., 2021) implementation of CKKS does not exhibit this property.

Case 3: DCGD with PermK

Both GD/AES and DCGD/AES require a significant amount of data to be sent from the master to the clients. In the case of using correlated compressors as PermK, all clients do not intersect in supports of sparsified gradients by design. The encryption of the global direction can be obtained by concatenating encrypted messages from clients. When using PermK, clients do not need to perform any aggregation on their side, and decryption of the whole global direction obtained from master can be done in 𝒪​(d)𝒪𝑑\mathcal{O}(d) independent on n𝑛n. We aim to find an approximate γ𝛾\gamma for DCGD/PermK. We generated 555 problems with matrices Ai∼U​[0,1)ni×dsimilar-tosubscript𝐴𝑖𝑈superscript01subscript𝑛𝑖𝑑A_{i}\sim U[0,1)^{n_{i}\times d}, projected A=[A1,…,An]⊤𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑛topA=[A_{1},\dots,A_{n}]^{\top} to have Lf=10subscript𝐿𝑓10L_{f}=10, and computed bi=defAi​xfixedsuperscriptdefsubscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖subscript𝑥fixedb_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}A_{i}x_{\mathrm{fixed}}. We tested various step sizes demonstrated in Fig. 5. We found that using a step size γ≥12​Lf=0.05𝛾12subscript𝐿𝑓0.05\gamma\geq\frac{1}{2L_{f}}=0.05 led to divergence, as shown in Fig. 5 (a), (b). From Fig. 5 (a), we see that the method exhibits linear convergence without oscillation near the solution, similar to DCGD with RandK (Here ∇fi​(x∗)=0,∀i∈[n]formulae-sequence∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥0for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\nabla f_{i}(x^{*})=0,\forall i\in[n], because d>ni⋅n𝑑⋅subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛d>n_{i}\cdot n). From Fig. 5 (c), we see that the variance of the optimization path using fixed step size γ=0.007𝛾0.007\gamma=0.007 and fixed d,ni,n,Lf𝑑subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛subscript𝐿𝑓d,n_{i},n,L_{f} is negligible.

Comparison of DCGD/PermK/AES and GD/CKKS

Fig. 6 compares GD, GD/CKKS, GD/PermK with GD/AES, GD/PermK/AES. We see that the CKKS schema does not leverage the sparsity of vectors, making sparsification-based compression ineffective in reducing communication during privacy-preserving training. Therefore, there is no benefit from using RandK for DCGD/CKKS, and it’s better to use vanilla GD. For GD, we used theoretical step size, which in practice is extremely tight. If communication isn’t free, Fig. 6 (a) and Fig. 6 (d) suggest that CKKS is impractical in settings where client-master communication is a bottleneck. Fig. 6 (b) shows that GD/AES does not increase client-to-master traffic but does significantly increase master-to-client traffic, as seen in Fig. 6 (d). If communication is free, Fig. 6 (c) shows that the best convergence in terms of rounds is attained for GD or GD/AES with preserving security. If communication is free, GD/CKKS remains suboptimal due to the approximate nature of floating-point operations in CKKS. Suppose the key metric is convergence in ‖∇f​(xk)‖norm∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘\|{\nabla f(x^{k})}\| relative to the number of bits from client to master. Fig. 6 (b) shows that GD/CKKS uses approximately 0.6⋅107⋅0.6superscript1070.6\cdot 10^{7} bits per client after the first round of optimization. DCGD/PermK/AES with this transfers can attain ‖∇f​(x)‖2≈10−20superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥2superscript1020\|{\nabla f(x)}\|^{2}\approx 10^{-20}.

5.2. Image Classification Application

We evaluated the applicability of using DCGD/PermK/AES on Deep Neural Networks training. We used the ResNet-18 architecture (He et al., 2016b) and trained it on the CIFAR-10 dataset (Krizhevsky and Hinton, 2009), which consists of 60 0006000060\,000 images across 101010 classes with a resolution of 32×32323232\times 32 pixels. We used ResNet-18 implementation from TorchVision library, part of the PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019). The model size d=11,181,642𝑑11181642d=11,181,642. For Optimization Problem 1, we used a standard cross-entropy loss for ℒi​jsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑗\mathcal{L}_{ij} terms in Equation 2. Next, we distributed the dataset uniformly across n=10𝑛10n=10 clients, with each client participating in every round. Global learning rate 0.10.10.1, local learning rate 0.10.10.1, local weight decay 5⋅10−4⋅5superscript1045\cdot 10^{-4}, number of rounds 5 00050005\,000. During each round, clients evaluate ∇fi​(x)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\nabla f_{i}(x) using a fixed 10% subset of each client’s local data points. In FL, there are cases where clients cannot store a large number of data points (e.g., high-resolution images, recorded voice in IoT devices) due to storage limitations. Our experiment simulates this scenario. We compared our implementation with FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), where no compression or encryption is performed. We tracked during training communicated message size, accuracy, and convergence. Our reported metrics in Fig. 7 are computation framework and communication topology independent. In these experiments, we did not carry out an analysis of the spent time for communication, compression, and AES encryption/decryption, because the actual numbers are highly implementation dependent quantities.

In DCGD/PermK/AES, the message size from the client to the master contains ⌈d10⌉=1,118,165𝑑101118165\left\lceil\frac{d}{10}\right\rceil=1,118,165 parameters with 444 bytes each one. The overhead from AES-128/EAX Operation Mode is 323232 bytes per single message, which is negligible. Fig. 7 shows that the message size was reduced from 42.6542.6542.65 (for FedAvg) MBytes to 4.264.264.26 MBytes (for DCGD/PermK). We cannot launch CKKS with security guarantees as AES-128 in our environment due to memory overhead. In Appendix 5.1, we demonstrated that problems start appearing in CKKS with AES-128 security guarantees already for d=106𝑑superscript106d=10^{6}. For a discussion about extra flexibility in Training DL models see Appendix I.

6. Deployment Flexibility

The Physical Network Topologies describes the arrangement of the computation and routing devices. In a Mesh topology, every pair of nodes is connected with a dedicated link. It has high bandwidth and fault tolerance but requires a lot of cables. In this setting, the DCGD/PermK is the natural choice. The Algorithm 3 can be observed as a series of broadcast operations to reconstitute the optimization step. The benefits to other topologies are discussed in Appendix J.

In Appendix H.2, we present the refined scheduled communication and computation plan that utilizes the possibility of computation communication overlap and handling computation heterogeneity during training Linear Regression. The modeled situation that we studied contained 555 clients (one of them is a straggler) which all are connected to the master with a shared channel. We demonstrated that the actual execution plan can be refined. The possible gained speedup for GD is ×1.31absent1.31\times 1.31, for DCGD/PermK is ×3.33absent3.33\times 3.33. The DCGD/PermK has flexibility to start several compute operations during waiting the straggler, which are limited for GD.

7. Conclusions

We proposed a novel secure FL framework that uses symmetric-key encryption with permutation compressors to protect the gradients during communication and simultaneously compress them. We conducted experiments on real and synthetic data. Additional studies about the effect of problem dimension, overlapping communication and computation, and deployment options in various network topologies are presented in Appendices H,  J. Our work opens a new possibility for applying Classical Cryptography to FL and challenges some existing claims about its limitations. Possible future research and current limitations are described in Appendix M.

Appendix D Overview of Existing Privacy Mechanisms in Context of FL

Trusted Execution Environments (TEE)

The TEE brings the idea of handling self-isolation of processes more seriously than it has been done in the Operation Systems before. An example of the particular implementation of this idea is ARM TrustZone (Pinto and Santos, 2019) and Intel SGX (Costan and Devadas, 2016), where both technologies have been implemented at the hardware level. Such technologies allow the protection of memory from reading and writing operations not only from another process in the Operation System (OS) but also from the kernel of the OS by itself. The goal of TEE:

TEE protects the execution environment from illegal intervention, which will defect training.

Differential Privacy (DP)

The goal of DP is to ensure statistical analysis does not hurt the privacy aspect. The intuitive definition can be as follows: "An algorithm A is differentially private if an observer seeing its output cannot tell if a particular individual’s data was used in the computation." DP criteria assess the private property of the algorithm, but it does not dictate how this functionality should be implemented. In general, as more noise is appending the data or derived quantities from the data that are released publicly, the algorithm starts to be more DP, but from another side, the statistical properties of the data for the purpose of solving original task start to be loosed.

Definition 1 (Approximate Differential Privacy).

An algorithm M:𝒳n→𝒴:𝑀→superscript𝒳𝑛𝒴M:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathcal{Y} satisfies approximate (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) - DP if ∀X,X′∈𝒳nfor-all𝑋superscript𝑋′superscript𝒳𝑛\forall X,X^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n} such that datasets are different in one point (neighboring datasets denoted as X∼X′similar-to𝑋superscript𝑋′X\sim X^{\prime}) and ∀T⊆𝒴for-all𝑇𝒴\forall T\subseteq\mathcal{Y} the following holds:

P​[M​(X)∈T]≤exp⁡(ε)​P​[M​(X′)∈T]+δ𝑃delimited-[]𝑀𝑋𝑇𝜀𝑃delimited-[]𝑀superscript𝑋′𝑇𝛿P[M(X)\in T]\leq\exp(\varepsilon)P[M(X^{\prime})\in T]+\delta

The definition 1 is a relaxation of pure-DP, first proposed by Dwork et al. in (Dwork et al., 2006a) in 2006. The pure-DP was given by in (Dwork et al., 2006b), requiring δ=0𝛿0\delta=0. The Approximate DP possesses weaker privacy guarantees but allows the addition of less noise.

DP-ERM aims to output θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta}, which is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) - DP with respect to the training dataset D𝐷D. To do that, there are three types of approaches: (1) Output perturbation; (2) Objective perturbation; (3) Gradient perturbation. Algorithms that solves that DP-ERM problem are quantified by expected excess empirical risk 𝐄​[ℒe​r​m​(θ^,D)−ℒe​r​m​(θe​r​m∗,D)]𝐄delimited-[]subscriptℒ𝑒𝑟𝑚^𝜃𝐷subscriptℒ𝑒𝑟𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑒𝑟𝑚𝐷\mathbf{E}[\mathcal{L}_{erm}(\hat{\theta},D)-\mathcal{L}_{erm}(\theta_{erm}^{*},D)], and for DP-RM problem by expected population risk 𝐄​[ℒr​m​(θ^,D)−ℒr​m​(θr​m∗,D)]𝐄delimited-[]subscriptℒ𝑟𝑚^𝜃𝐷subscriptℒ𝑟𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑟𝑚𝐷\mathbf{E}[\mathcal{L}_{rm}(\hat{\theta},D)-\mathcal{L}_{rm}(\theta_{rm}^{*},D)]. These quantities are sometimes named as utility.
The goal of DP:

DP protects output of algorithms so that users’ data are not leaking from Algorithm execution.

One important classification in DP algorithms targeted to distributed environments is their separation into two classes: Centralized and Local Differential Private settings. In the centralized model, a client trusts curator (or master) and DP protection mechanism are applied in master. In the local model, each individual applies a differential private mechanism to their own data before sending it to an untrusted curator (or master). Centralized models have lower privacy loss, since the noise is added only once at the end of the process such as aggregation at master. However, the centralized model also requires more trust in the aggregator.

Aggregation with Multi-Party Computation (MPC)

The MPC is a sub-field of Cryptography concerned with the problem of having a set of parties that compute an agreed function of their private inputs. The goal of secure multi-party computation (MPC) is to enable independent data owners who do not trust each other or any common third party to jointly compute a function that depends on all of their private inputs. MPC protocols are typically implemented with (a) Secret sharing - in this case, it requires a lot of total communication rounds to compute the average across n𝑛n clients; (b) Garbled circuits - in this case there both communication and computation overhead is added to the training (Zhao et al., 2019). The goal of MPC:

MPC allows for protecting inputs for the algorithm at the cost of communication.

Homomorphic Encryption (HE)

Homomorphic Encryption (HE) enables numerical computation on encrypted data, e.g. aggregating vectors from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. However, the result can only be decrypted with the private key. The concept dates back to 1978 when R. L. Rivest et al. (Rivest et al., 1978) proposed this but without a complete solution. HE allows any device party to compute functions on encrypted data using only a public key and encrypt the result. HE aims to hide the plaintext input and output from the executor, who only sees the encrypted versions of it. This is possible with HE. On the other hand, obfuscation is the process of encrypting the program (function f𝑓f), not the input or output from the caller. Obfuscation is impossible under weak technical conditions (Barak et al., 2001).

Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) allows any computable algorithm to be executed on encrypted data without any restrictions on the binary operations. The first FHE scheme was proposed by Craig Gentry (Gentry, 2009), based on lattices and a novel bootstrapping technique. Let cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} be the encryption of message misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}, and c𝑐c be the result of evaluating a function f^​(c1,…​cn)^𝑓subscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑛\hat{f}(c_{1},\dots c_{n}), which should decrypt to m=f​(m1,…​mn)𝑚𝑓subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑛m=f(m_{1},\dots m_{n}). In his Ph.D. thesis, C. Gentry listed some requirements that any FHE scheme should satisfy, which we summarize below:

  1. (1)

    Correctness: Decryption should always recover the correct evaluation of the function, i.e., P​(D​e​c​r​y​p​t​(c)=f​(m1,m2,…)=1)𝑃𝐷𝑒𝑐𝑟𝑦𝑝𝑡𝑐𝑓subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2…1P({Decrypt(c)=f(m_{1},m_{2},\dots)}=1).

  2. (2)

    Semantic security: The encryption of any two messages should be computationally indistinguishable.

  3. (3)

    Efficiency: Decryption should not be more expensive than evaluating the function itself.

  4. (4)

    Compactness: Ciphertexts should have a polynomial size in the security parameter, independent of the size of the function evaluated.

  5. (5)

    Security: The best-known attack should have exponential complexity in the security parameter, i.e., Ω​(2k)Ωsuperscript2𝑘\Omega({2^{k}}) (k𝑘k is a security parameter).

  6. (6)

    Feasibility: Key generation, encryption, and decryption should have polynomial complexity in the security parameter.

By C.Gentry, only algorithms that allow executing any computable algorithm on encrypted data that satisfies properties (1) - (6) can be called FHE. The FHE with this requirement can firstly be hard to construct, and secondary in practice, they may not be computationally efficient. To mitigate these issues, two main strategies are the following:

  • •

    Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption (SWHE). One way to make FHE more efficient in practice is to restrict the class of functions that can be evaluated. This leads to Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption, which can handle functions from restricted classes (e.g. they are low-degree polynomials).

  • •

    Leveled FHE (LFHE). Another way is to limit the depth of the binary circuit that represents the function. This leads to a notion of Leveled FHE, which can handle arbitrary functions represented by boolean circuits but with a fixed bound on the circuit depth.

Challenges of applying HE for training Machine Learning models and scientific computation:

  1. (1)

    The HE adds noise to the plaintext to ensure security. The challenge is to manage it with error-correction techniques, as it typically grows after each arithmetic operation.

  2. (2)

    The HE cannot perform random access on encrypted data without revealing information.

  3. (3)

    The HE cannot exploit the advantages of Random Access Machines, which can compute some algorithms faster than binary circuits, e.g., Binary Search.

  4. (4)

    The HE does not support multiple keys natively. Originally, it was designed as a single-private-key system.

  5. (5)

    The HE does not obfuscate the function itself, only the input and output. As mentioned, obfuscation is impossible under weak conditions (Barak et al., 2001).

  6. (6)

    The HE works on binary circuits or functional schemas. This class of representation is Turing Complete, assuming we can create circuits of different levels for different inputs. The pure FHE operations are computationally intensive and currently for practical purposes the SWHE and LFHE schemas should be considered instead.

  7. (7)

    The HE methods require large ciphertext sizes.

  8. (8)

    Choosing the right HE scheme for a given machine learning task is not trivial.

The goal of HE:

HE allows meaningful manipulation under encrypted data without revealing it.

Appendix E Discussions

E.1. The Imperative of Safeguarding Against Eavesdropping

Assume that during training with first-order optimization method, each client i𝑖i discloses the following information at each iteration k∈1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k\in{1,\dots,K}:

∂fi​(xk)∂xj=deflimd​xj→0fi​(xk+ek⋅d​xj;Di)−f​(xk;Di)d​xj.superscriptdefsubscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗subscript→𝑑subscript𝑥𝑗0subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑘⋅subscript𝑒𝑘𝑑subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝐷𝑖𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝐷𝑖𝑑subscript𝑥𝑗\dfrac{\partial f_{i}(x^{k})}{\partial x_{j}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\lim_{dx_{j}\to 0}\dfrac{f_{i}(x^{k}+e_{k}\cdot{dx}_{j};{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}})-f(x^{k};{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}})}{{dx}_{j}}.

If fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is twice differentiable and has bounded Hessians near point xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k}, the knowledge of partial derivative approximates the following equality: ∂fi​(xk)∂xj⋅d​xj≈fi​(xk+ej⋅d​xj;Di)−f​(xj;Di)⋅subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗𝑑subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝑥𝑘⋅subscript𝑒𝑗𝑑subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝐷𝑖𝑓superscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝐷𝑖\dfrac{\partial f_{i}(x^{k})}{\partial x_{j}}\cdot dx_{j}\approx{f_{i}(x^{k}+e_{j}\cdot{dx}_{j};{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}})-f(x^{j};{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}})}. In the last approximate equality, ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j} is a unit norm vector of the standard basis of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. Let’s assume that:

  1. (1)

    The fi​(x)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x) is linear with respect to Disubscript𝐷𝑖{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}} in original form, or there exists a bijective change of variable Di→Di′→subscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖′{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}\to{D_{i}}^{\prime}} such that fi​(x)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x) is linear in Di′superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖′{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}^{\prime}}.

  2. (2)

    Iterates xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} are uniformly distributed in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Under these assumptions, a training process might reveal sensitive information. Indeed, if an adversary obtains this information, then information about partial derivative provides noisy response linear function in Disubscript𝐷𝑖{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}}. This general setting has been studied by (Dinur and Nissim, 2003). Authors demonstrated that there exist linear attacks that could, with high probability, expose Disubscript𝐷𝑖{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}}.

Specifically, let’s denote the length of Disubscript𝐷𝑖{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}} is equal to N𝑁N bits. Let’s assume adversarial obtains K𝐾K noisy answers (for a single partial derivative) with an additive error of E=o​(N)𝐸𝑜𝑁E=o(\sqrt{N}) to each answer. Having K≥θ​(N2/E2)𝐾𝜃superscript𝑁2superscript𝐸2K\geq\theta(N^{2}/E^{2}), such adversarial queries can reveal information about Disubscript𝐷𝑖{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}} with high probability. The hidden constant is around 256256256 but can be improved. A single full gradient ∇fi​(x;Di)∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript𝐷𝑖\nabla f_{i}(x;{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{1,0,0}D_{i}}) provides d𝑑d equations instead of 111 for each response. This demonstrates that in specific modes the pretty big amount of partial derivative already reveals enough information to reconstruct the client’s dataset. Such attacks are not only in theoretical interest but can be practically mounted (Cohen and Nissim, 2018), (Kasiviswanathan et al., 2013).

E.2. Privacy and Security

As we have described in Appendix D, different mechanisms can be used for FL to provide privacy for different aspects training process. Each mechanism has a specific target of protection (such as input, output, execution, or communication channel) and a specific adversary model. The precise meaning of protection is defined by rigorous formalization and the details are crucial. For example, DP protects the output of an algorithm so that it does not reveal sensitive information about the input data, while MPC protects the input data from being exposed to other parties during computation. Recent research papers on FL deployments have mostly used Local DP (Bhowmick et al., 2018), or a combination of MPC and centralized DP.

In contrast, the proposed design in our work can be understood as a mechanism for providing security for the training process rather than privacy. The response obtained from the server by the client is computed securely and accurately with protection against attacks on the server or the communication channels to the server. The notion of privacy covers the guarantee that the target of protection can participate in an algorithm without being observed by unauthorized parties. Security, on the other hand, can be considered as a more holistic concept that specifies: the algorithm or protocol, how personal information and derived quantities are protected, the type and strength of attacks that are resisted, and the requirement of having a secret key to access the data. Sometimes, a complex security protocol may not be feasible or desirable for certain situations, and a privacy mechanism that is less comprehensive but more flexible may be a better choice.

Appendix F Usage of AES cipher during Distributed Training

This section overviews the current state-of-the-art block cipher AES and explains how it can be used for symmetric key encryption in scenarios where multiple client messages must be encrypted and decrypted securely.

F.1. AES Block Cipher

A block cipher is a fundamental cryptographic primitive that transforms a fixed-length block of bits into another block of the same length using a secret key. The AES is today’s most widely used secure block cipher. Some CPUs have hardware support for it. Examples of CPUs with x86 instruction set architecture that support AES in the hardware level are Intel Westmere, AMD Bulldozer, and ARM AARCH64 instruction set architecture example is ARM Cortex-A53.

AES block cipher supports three key sizes: 128128128, 192192192, or 256256256. The key size determines the level of security and the computational cost of the encryption and decryption operations. The key space K𝐾K for AES-128 has size of |K|=2128𝐾superscript2128|K|=2^{128}. The input message space M𝑀M and the output cipher text space C𝐶C of the block cipher AES for all types of keys have the same size equal to 128128128 bits. Therefore cardinality of M𝑀M and C𝐶C is equal to |M|=|C|=2128𝑀𝐶superscript2128|M|=|C|=2^{128}.

For each key k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K, the AES block cipher maps M→C→𝑀𝐶M\to C with a bijective function, with M=C𝑀𝐶M=C, and |M|=|C|≤∞𝑀𝐶|M|=|C|\leq\infty. Essentially, the key k𝑘k is a selector of bijective mapping or permutation. Each key realizes the permutation of the input message. If we assume that each of two distinct keys k1,k2∈Ksubscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2𝐾k_{1},k_{2}\in K implements different bijective mappings M→C→𝑀𝐶M\to C, then the number of permutations that AES can realize is |K|=2128𝐾superscript2128|K|=2^{128}. Even though it’s a big number, this is much smaller than 2128!superscript21282^{128}!, all possible permutations if input and output are 128128128 bits in length. In the Cryptography community, the block cipher AES is sometimes observed as a primitive that implements a Pseudo Random Permutation (PRP). In other words, this means that for a fixed key, it defines a permutation. The discrepancy between the number of all possible permutations and the number of PRPs that AES can realize is elegantly resolved in the Cryptography community. It is resolved by introducing the notion of a Secure PRP. The algorithm which implements PRP implements a Secure PRP if an adversary from observing the realization of permutation f𝑓f cannot distinguish by using an arbitrarily tractable algorithm between two events:

  1. (1)

    The permutation function f:M→M:𝑓→𝑀𝑀f:M\to M is chosen uniformly at random from all possible M!𝑀M! permutations.

  2. (2)

    The permutation function f:M→M:𝑓→𝑀𝑀f:M\to M is chosen as one of the permutations that block cipher BlockCipher​(⋅,k):M→M:BlockCipher⋅𝑘→𝑀𝑀\mathrm{BlockCipher}(\cdot,k):M\to M with k∼u.a.rKsubscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequence𝑢𝑎𝑟𝑘𝐾k\sim_{u.a.r}K can realize.

By the current status in Cryptography, the AES is believed to be a secure PRP. Having two input and output pairs, adversarial may wish to derive the secret key. The brute force search on AES-128 is computationally infeasible because 2128superscript21282^{128} is too large to enumerate. The best-known attack on the full version of AES-128 that can recover the complete key has a complexity of 2126superscript21262^{126} (Bogdanov et al., 2011). The AES-128 is secure against brute force search and also against linear and quantum attacks (Jang et al., 2022).

F.2. Internals of AES Block Cipher

The AES block cipher has 101010 rounds for AES-128 and 141414 rounds for AES-256. The key is expanded into 111111 or 151515 subkeys of 128128128 bits in length each. Subkeys are used in each round. Each round consists of four invertible steps: key addition (in the sense of exclusive boolean or, which we will denote as XOR), byte substitution, row shift, and column mix. These steps transform a 4×4444\times 4 matrix of bytes representing each round’s input. Byte substitution adds non-linearity, row shift rotates each row cyclically, and column mix applies a linear transformation to each column. The last subkey is used for a final key addition (XOR) to mask the output. The AES decryption reverses the encryption steps. The AES has different implementations for different devices and code size requirements. All occurred transformations are stateless; consequently, the AES block cipher is stateless.

F.3. Apply AES Block Cipher for more than one input block

The AES is a secure block cipher, but it is a bad idea to use the same key k𝑘k to encrypt multiple blocks deterministically. This breaks the notion of Semantic Security, which essentially means that adversarial can deduce some information from analyzing sequences of ciphertexts from the block cipher (e.g. adversarial can, from observing c1=c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1}=c_{2} conclude that m1=m2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1}=m_{2}, even adversarial does not know exactly values m1,m2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1},m_{2}). To preserve Semantic Security, the encryption should have protection from chosen-plaintext-attack, which informally denotes this kind of attack.

Formally, in chosen-plaintext-attack (CPA) an attacker may adaptively ask for the encryption (e1,e2,…)subscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2…(e_{1},e_{2},\dots) of arbitrary messages (m1,m2,…)subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2…(m_{1},m_{2},\dots) of his choice. The attacker’s goal is to obtain the ability to correctly guess from two obtained encryption {ea,eb}subscript𝑒𝑎subscript𝑒𝑏\{e_{a},e_{b}\} from experiment A𝐴A and experiment B𝐵B which encryption belongs to which message from the set {ma,mb}subscript𝑚𝑎subscript𝑚𝑏\{m_{a},m_{b}\}. The attacker does not know encryption of {ma,mb}subscript𝑚𝑎subscript𝑚𝑏\{m_{a},m_{b}\} in advance, and the attacker does not know which plain message has been used in which experiment. In the context of this attack, the advantage of adversarial is defined as:

A​D​Vc​p​a=|P​({ExperimentA​uses​ma})−P​({ExperimentB​uses​mb})|.𝐴𝐷subscript𝑉𝑐𝑝𝑎𝑃ExperimentAusessubscript𝑚𝑎𝑃ExperimentBusessubscript𝑚𝑏{ADV}_{cpa}=|P(\{\mathrm{ExperimentA\,uses\,}m_{a}\})-P(\{\mathrm{ExperimentB\,uses\,}m_{b}\})|.

Fundamentally, there are two ways to provide security against CPA attacks:

  1. (1)

    Increase ciphertext space and allow encryption to work randomly. This is the underlying reason why CKKS is CPA secure. The downside of this is that ciphertext space is increasing.

  2. (2)

    Augment key space K𝐾K with extra counter, named as a nonce from a nonce space N𝑁N. The clients who perform encryption guarantee that the pair (k​e​y,n​o​n​c​e)𝑘𝑒𝑦𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒(key,nonce) is unique during the life of the k𝑘k. The n​o​n​c​e𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒nonce is open to everybody.

Next, there are two different ways to select nonce in nonce-based protection against CPA attacks:

  1. (1)

    Deterministic counter. In this mode, a single deterministic integer counter is used. Sometimes there is no need to send nonce itself with ciphertext during communication if the receiver of ciphertext can recover counter from other information.

  2. (2)

    Randomized counter. If encryption happens on several devices, the coordination of nonce complicates the process. One way around this is to select n​o​n​c​e∼u.a.r.Nsubscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequence𝑢𝑎𝑟𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒𝑁nonce\sim_{u.a.r.}N, where N𝑁N is sufficiently large, e.g. |N|>2128𝑁superscript2128|N|>2^{128}. Such nonce space size will guarantee that we expect to obtain during the sampling at least one collision after sampling 2​|N|+1=2642𝑁1superscript264\sqrt{2|N|}+1=2^{64} due to the famous Birthday Paradox.

The two popular ways to use nonce-based encryption for AES, also known as Operation Modes, are the following:

  1. (1)

    Nonce-based Cipher Block Chaining Mode (CBC). In this schema, the input message is split into buckets. These inputs are substituted into AES block cipher, but the inputs themselves are masked before encryption. The first plaintext bucket is masked (via XOR) with nonce. Other plaintext buckets are masked (via XOR) with the output from AES block cipher operated in the previous block. The output of this mechanism is the public nonce and sequence of encrypted input buckets. It can be proved that AES/CPA secure with advantage A​D​Vc​p​a≤1/232𝐴𝐷subscript𝑉𝑐𝑝𝑎1superscript232{ADV}_{cpa}\leq 1/2^{32} if use CBC for 248superscript2482^{48} AES (128128128 bits) blocks. If nonce is generated with non-secure PRG, then it should be firstly encrypted by itself with secure AES Block to generate secure nonce.

  2. (2)

    Randomized Counter Mode (CTR). The input message is split into buckets. But in this mode, the mask for each bucket i𝑖i is generated with AES block cipher 𝖠𝖤𝖲​(k,n​o​n​c​e+i)𝖠𝖤𝖲𝑘𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒𝑖{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}\sf\small{AES}}(k,nonce+i). The input bucket is masked with this value 𝖠𝖤𝖲​(k,n​o​n​c​e+i)𝖠𝖤𝖲𝑘𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒𝑖{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}\sf\small{AES}}(k,nonce+i) via XOR operation. It can be shown to guarantee CPA security with the advantage 1/2321superscript2321/2^{32} for it the number of transferred messages with AES should be at most 264superscript2642^{64} AES Blocks. In addition, this operation mode is more flexible in contrast to CBC because this mode does not require any padding and can be implemented by discarding not needed bits in the last bucket.

The CKKS and AES in EAX mode of operation (Bellare et al., 2004) are secure against CPA attacks.

F.4. Apply AES with Integrity Guarantees

The CPA security and operations mode solve security against eavesdropping, but they don’t provide integrity of the delivered messages. Message Authentication Code(MAC) is Cryptography protected analogous to (non-secure) Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC), which is used in Networking communication to protect from random (not adversarial) noise in communication channels. The goal of MAC is that the value of MAC coupled with a ciphertext guarantees that the message has not been modified during the transfer by the adversary. The signing algorithm for generating MAC tag takes a plain message m𝑚m and secret key k𝑘k as input. The signature is added to the transferred message with the public nonce. Adversarial without a secret key k𝑘k cannot produce valid (M​e​s​s​a​g​e,M​a​c)𝑀𝑒𝑠𝑠𝑎𝑔𝑒𝑀𝑎𝑐(Message,Mac) pairs in such a way that it will pass the verification algorithm. The verification algorithm takes as input the secret key k𝑘k, decrypted message m𝑚m, and MAC value t​a​g𝑡𝑎𝑔tag. In practice, nonce and MAC are typically 161616 bytes long. If the optimization algorithm already requires sending far more than 222 elements of ℝℝ\mathbb{R} encoded in IEEE-754 FP64 format then this overhead is negligible during the training.

Two popular constructions to provide integrity in the context of AES are the following:

  1. (1)

    Encrypted CBC-MAC. The input message is split into 161616 bytes buckets. After this, the first bucket is plugged into AES as input. Output from this block is masked with XOR with the next input 161616 byte bucket. After the XOR operation is finished, the output of XOR is plugged into the next AES block as input, and the process repeats in a chaining fashion. It is important to notice that all AES blocks use the same key k𝑘k. Finally, the last output is plugged into one more AES block as input, which uses another key k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} and schema releases MAC tag.

  2. (2)

    Nested MAC. In this approach, the message is split into 161616 bytes buckets. After this, the first AES block obtains as input this first bucket and k𝑘k is used as a secret key. The output of this AES block is used as a key for the next block, and data for this AES block is the next input bucket. After processing all messages, the last output is plugged into the last AES block as input, but for the last AES block, another secret key k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} should be used similarly as in CBC-MAC.

For using CBC-MAC and Nested MAC securely, the number of signed messages (of arbitrary length) should be on the order of 264superscript2642^{64} AES 128128128-bits blocks. For details, please check the analysis of these schemes.

F.5. Chosen Ciphertext Attack CCA and Authentication

In a chosen ciphertext attack (CCA), the attacker has access to a decryption oracle and can decrypt any ciphertext of his choice. Also, the attacker can access encryption oracles and obtain encryption of arbitrary messages of his choice. Adversarial aims to break semantic security in the CPA sense. To provide the CCA security, the two processes Encrypt and MAC should be performed sequentially, and typically it’s preferable to perform them in this order. In our paper, we have used EAX, which is CTR mode for encryption combined with CMAC for integrity purposes.

F.6. Using AES with EAX Operation Mode in our paper

We use AES encryption with EAX mode, which produces a triple as output:

⟨m=Ci(∇f(xt)∈ℝd(16/32/64⋅dbits),nonce∈N(128bits),Tag(128bits,ciphertext)⟩\langle m=C_{i}(\nabla f(x^{t})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}(16/32/64\cdot d\,\mathrm{bits}),nonce\in N(128\,\mathrm{bits}),Tag(128\,\mathrm{bits},ciphertext)\rangle

.

The ciphertext has the same bit length as the original message. Because EAX mode employs CTR for stream encryption, it does not require any padding. The n​o​n​c​e𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑐𝑒nonce is a random 16-byte value, and the T​a​g𝑇𝑎𝑔Tag is a 161616 byte message authentication code. As it has been mentioned in Section 4, the CKKS and all HE schemas cannot achieve CCA security (Fauzi et al., 2022). For AES/EAX, it has been proved in (Bellare et al., 2004) that it’s secure against CCA attacks. Cryptography is an area of science by itself. Readers for can gain more information about Classical Cryptography from (Boneh and Shoup, 2020).

Appendix G Homomorphic Encryption with CKKS

G.1. Learning With Errors Problem and REGEV09 Algorithm as a Concrete Example of SWHE

The security of the CKKS scheme depends mainly on the hardness of the Learning With Errors(LWE) problem which we will overview next. The "Learning with errors" search problem represents was analyzed in (Regev, 2009). For this work Oded Regev has obtained a Gödel prize in 2018:

find​s∈ℤqnfind𝑠superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\displaystyle\mathrm{find}\,s\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}
such​that:sT​𝐀+eT:suchthatsuperscript𝑠𝑇𝐀superscript𝑒𝑇\displaystyle\mathrm{such\,that:}\,s^{T}\mathbf{A}+e^{T} =b​where​e​is​r.v.formulae-sequenceabsent𝑏where𝑒isrv\displaystyle=b\,\mathrm{where}\,e\,\mathrm{is\,r.v.}

Parameters have the following properties:

  • •

    The q𝑞q is a prime number.

  • •

    m>n𝑚𝑛m>n.

  • •

    𝐀∈ℤqn×m𝐀superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛𝑚\mathbf{A}\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n\times m} is a random matrix drawn u.a.r. from ℤqn×msuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛𝑚\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n\times m}.

  • •

    β∈ℝ𝛽ℝ\beta\in\mathbb{R}.

  • •

    e∈ℤqm𝑒superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑚e\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{m} is small (in terms of L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm) r.v. For r.v. e𝑒e there is no assumption about its distribution. The only one constraint is that e≠0𝑒0e\neq 0.

As can be observed from the description LWE problem operates on a system of over-determined sets of equations. When e=0𝑒0e=0 the system can be solved via Gaussian elimination, but when e≠0𝑒0e\neq 0 we believe it’s a hard search problem. Specifically, Theorem 1 from (Regev, 2009) makes a connection between LWE and the search problem in integer lattices via the following theorem:

Instance of LWE problems with parameter n𝑛n is as hard as the Short Integer Solution Problem.

The best well-known solution for solving the LWE problem works in the following time: q𝒪​(n/log⁡(n))superscript𝑞𝒪𝑛𝑛{q}^{\mathcal{O}\left({n}/{\log(n)}\right)} (Blum et al., 2003).

There exists a variation of the LWE problem named as Decision Learning With Errors problem. In theory, it has been shown that Decisional LWE is as hard as LWE. In usual LWE we can not find a solution for a noisy set of linear equations effectively based on knowledge of A𝐴A and b𝑏b. In Decisional LWE the adversaries can not from observing tuple (𝐀,b)𝐀𝑏(\mathbf{A},b) distinguish the following two scenarios:

  1. (1)

    The tuple (𝐀,b)𝐀𝑏(\mathbf{A},b) has been generated completely uniformly at random. In some sense, there are no real hidden linear dependence structures between columns of A𝐴A and b𝑏b.

  2. (2)

    The tuple (𝐀,b)𝐀𝑏(\mathbf{A},b) in fact has a specific structure (𝐀=𝐀,b=𝐀T​s+e)formulae-sequence𝐀𝐀𝑏superscript𝐀𝑇𝑠𝑒(\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{A},b=\mathbf{A}^{T}s+e).

The LWE problem provides a way to publish a lot of perturbated linear equations in variable s𝑠s in the form of sT​𝐀+eT=bsuperscript𝑠𝑇𝐀superscript𝑒𝑇𝑏s^{T}\mathbf{A}+e^{T}=b, and essentially hide s∈ℤn𝑠superscriptℤ𝑛s\in\mathbb{Z}^{n} from parties who do not know exactly e𝑒e.

Next, we will describe concrete examples of using this idea. The method described next represents a symmetric Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption (SWHE) Learning With Errors (LWE) based scheme known as REGEV09. The method was proposed in 2009 at work (Regev, 2009). Its security properties are based on hardness to solve the decisional LWE.

KeyGen.

s∈ℤqn∼U𝑠superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛similar-to𝑈s\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}\sim U is a secret key, q𝑞q is a prime, n𝑛n is a secure parameter.

Encrypt.

Encryption is working bit by bit. The message that we encrypt without loss of generality can be considered as m∈{0,1}𝑚01m\in\{0,1\}. The algorithm for encryption produces ciphertext as c=(a,b)∈ℤqn×ℤq𝑐𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛subscriptℤ𝑞c=(a,b)\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}\times\mathbb{Z}_{q} via following rules:

  1. (1)

    e∈ℤ𝑒ℤe\in\mathbb{Z} is a "short" noise generated from some distribution, satisfied constraint |e|<q/4𝑒𝑞4|e|<q/4).

  2. (2)

    a∈ℤqn𝑎superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛a\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n} is a random vector sampled uniformly from its domain.

  3. (3)

    b=def⟨a,s⟩+e+(m⋅⌊q/2⌋)|modqb\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\langle a,s\rangle+e+(m\cdot\left\lfloor q/2\right\rfloor)|\mod q.

  4. (4)

    The released ciphertext c=(a,b)∈ℤqn×ℤq𝑐𝑎𝑏superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛subscriptℤ𝑞c=(a,b)\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}\times\mathbb{Z}_{q}

Decrypt.

Decryption happens via using the following formula which involves function r​o​u​n​da​(x)𝑟𝑜𝑢𝑛subscript𝑑𝑎𝑥{round}_{a}(x) which round to 00 or a𝑎a depends on what is more close to x𝑥x.

For decryption to work correctly, we need to have e∈(−⌊q/4⌋,⌊q/4⌋)𝑒𝑞4𝑞4e\in(-\left\lfloor q/4\right\rfloor,\left\lfloor q/4\right\rfloor).
